Graphical abstract Carbon fiber-based self-supported has excellent catalytic performance and can be further improved by various modifications under the guidance of the regulatory strategies of size, defect, strain, interface effect, and so on. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the key reactions in numerous renewable energy devices. Unlike conventional powdered catalysts, self-supported catalysts are extensively employed in oxygen electrocatalysis because of the enhanced electron-transfer rate, high specific surface area, and superior mechanical flexibility. Among the self-supported conductive substrates, carbon fiber usually exhibits several distinctive advantages, such as a straightforward preparation process, relatively low cost, good stability, and excellent conductivity. Against this background, carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts have been widely applied and studied in oxygen electrocatalysis, indicating a promising development direction in oxygen electrocatalyst research. Thus, it is essential to offer an overall summary of the research progress in this field to facilitate its subsequent development. Taking the regulatory mechanisms and modification methods as a starting point, this review comprehensively summarizes recent research on carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts in recent years. Firstly, a brief overview of the synthesis methods and regulatory mechanisms of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts is given. Furthermore, the view also highlights the modification methods and research progress of self-supported electrocatalysts synthesized on carbon fiber-based substrates in recent years in terms of different dopant atoms. Finally, the prospects for the application of self-supported electrocatalysts based on carbon fiber in oxygen electrocatalysis and the possible future directions of their development are presented. This review summarizes recent developments and applications of self-supported bi-functional electrocatalysts with carbon fiber-based materials as the conducting substrate in oxygen electrocatalysis. It also lays a robust scientific foundation for the subsequent reasonable design of highly effective carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts. Keywords Carbon fiber Self-supported electrocatalysts ORR OER 1 Introduction The problems of energy and environmental crisis have caused considerable concerns worldwide in recent years, and the development of renewable and environmentally friendly new energy to substitute conventional fossil fuels also become a new research objective in the energy field [1]. Among all renewable energy sources being investigated, metal-air batteries and fuel cells are ideal candidates for emerging energy sources due to their high energy density and low environmental impact [2]. In metal-air batteries, metal Li, Zn, Al, and Mg are often used as metallic electrodes [3]. Among all metal electrodes, zinc electrodes are more adaptable to aqueous electrolytes. Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) composed of zinc electrodes can generate power by the reaction between external oxygen and the zinc anode. This can achieve zero carbon emissions, well meeting the requirements of a low-carbon economy. All in all, ZABs have received increasing focus for their high corrosion resistance, high capacity, and safety in alkaline environments. Nevertheless, the practical application of high-performance ZABs is constrained by the low reaction rates of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) on air cathodes and Zn anodes respectively [4]. Furthermore, the bi-functional activity of electrocatalysts is seriously limited by the scalar relation, thus requiring the development and design of efficient catalysts to accelerate their kinetics [5]. However, the catalysts currently used for ORR and OER are noble metal catalysts, including Pt/C, RuO2, etc. [6], which generally suffer from the disadvantages of scarcity and high costs [7], significantly hindering the commercialization progressions of high-performance ZABs. Thus, developing efficient, sustainable, and inexpensive bi-functional catalysts without noble metals is currently a major topic in electrocatalysis. Typical non-precious metal catalysts mainly include transition metals and their compounds, heteroatom-doped carbon-based materials, and various nanocarbon-loaded hybrid materials. Up to now, most of the catalysts used for oxygen electrocatalysis are conventional powder catalysts, which typically require mixing with polymeric binders (e.g. polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), Nafion, etc.) and solvents to form the final catalyst, which can be oven-dried and then coated onto conductive collectors to form the final electrode [8], but this is a cumbersome process and also has some drawbacks as following. (1) Binders are required for bonding the powdered catalyst to the conducting substrate, which seriously affects the electron conductivity and mechanical stability of the cell electrodes [9,10]. (2) If the electrodes are immersed in strong alkaline solutions for a long time, these polymer binders will be severely degraded, greatly shortening the life of the battery [11,12]. (3) The application of organic solvents as binders and electrocatalysts has safety, environmental, and health implications [13]. (4) The use of binders also has the effect of reducing the active area of the catalyst to a certain degree, blocking mass transfer channels, and lowering catalyst catalytic efficiency [14–16]. Therefore, the preparation of self-supported electrocatalysts with electrocatalytic performance is a prerequisite for alleviating the bottleneck of existing powder catalysts. All in all, the advantages of self-supported electrocatalyst systems are as follows. (1) The direct growing and anchoring of catalysts on conducting substrates can effectively increase the loading capacity and further enhance the number of active sites [17]. (2) The costs can be reduced by avoiding the use of expensive binders. (3) The choice of the right substrate materials will improve the reaction kinetics, enhancing the rate of charge and mass migration [18,19] (Fig. 1 a and b). Most studies have shown that the substrates used for self-supported electrocatalysts mainly can be classified into two types: conductive and non-conductive substrates, where the former can be divided into metal-based (metal foils, metal mesh, metal foam, etc.) and carbon-based (carbon nanofiber (CNFs), carbon fiber (CF), carbon cloth (CC), etc.). Compared with metal substrates, carbon-based materials are widely used in the field of electrochemistry due to their outstanding characteristics such as outstanding stability in strong alkaline environments, ease of handling, and low manufacturing costs [20,21]. Wang et al. [22] comprehensively reviewed the progress of carbon-based electrocatalysts in ORR/OER/HER (hydrogen evolution reaction). Among many carbon materials, carbon fiber-based materials are distinguished by their remarkable specific surface, large porosity, and excellent conductive meshing. In addition, the diffusion of solutes in solution is also greatly enhanced by its porous structure, which greatly enhances the electrocatalytic performance [1,23]. Moreover, carbon fiber usually can be easily produced by electrospinning technique, and carbon fabrics made of carbon fiber have some admirable advantages of lightness, high-temperature resistance, good mechanical flexibility, etc. Due to these properties, carbon fiber-based materials, especially CNFs and CC, are excellent substrate materials for self-supported electrodes. In addition, because of the excellent flexural endurance of carbon fiber-based conductive substrates, the flexible solid-state batteries assembled from carbon fiber-based self-supported electrodes are also important flexible energy storage devices [24]. In conclusion, carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts have an important and wide application prospect in oxygen electrocatalysis. Although the advantages of self-supported air electrodes, their synthesis methods, and their applications in ZABs have been previously summarized by researchers [25–27], no one has yet outlined the carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts alone for practical bi-functional oxygen electrocatalysis applications. Based on this background, the review provides a detailed summary of improved strategies and applications of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts in oxygen electrocatalysis (Fig. 2 ). Firstly, a brief overview is given for synthesizing carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts. Then, a brief description of the ORR/OER reaction mechanism and the regulatory mechanism is provided. Finally, the modification methods and research progress of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts in recent years are highlighted in terms of different dopant atoms and also give an outlook to their future research. The review is rather crucial for the advancement of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts in the future. 2 The preparation methods of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts Although many impressive results have been achieved in conventional powder electrocatalysts, it has been recognized that the use of binders can create a high resistance to oxygen transport. These ordinary binders are generally low active and insulating, which can lead to a reduction of the catalytic performance. What is even more serious is that the powder catalysts can detach from the substrate during use, which can lead to a serious degradation in the catalyst's performance. In this context, self-supported electrocatalysts in which the active substance is directly grown in-situ on the conducting substrates have received extensive attention from researchers. Self-supported electrocatalysts are materials grown in situ on a conductive substrate without the addition of any binders or additives. To ensure rational synthesis and modification, the following factors need to be considered: (1) catalyst components; (2) self-supported substrates; (3) synthesis methods. Under the influence of the carrier effect, the electronic structure can be reasonably altered by altering the electron transfer rate between the carrier and the loaded nanoparticles, which in turn also affects the catalytic performance [28]. Therefore, the final catalytic performance can be significantly influenced by selecting a suitable self-supported substrate. Secondly, the method used to deposit catalysts onto conducting substrates also significantly impacts the catalytic performance of self-supported catalysts and thus has made some researchers explore them in depth. For the past few years, there has been considerable development in self-supported electrocatalysts on carbon fiber-based conductive substrates. From a dimensional perspective, carbon fiber-based self-supported substrates can be further classified into CNFs, CF, CC, and others, all of which exhibit remarkable stability and wide acceptability for a variety of simple synthetic routes. The performance of the final catalyst can be significantly influenced by the reasonable choice and application of different synthesis methods. 2.1 Preparation of carbon nanofiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts Carbon nanofibers (CNFs) can produce a porous structure by certain methods, making them possess a considerable specific surface area and high activity performance among the carbon atoms at their edges. As a result, they can be employed as exemplary electrocatalyst carriers. Some researchers usually synthesize some functional CNFs through electrospinning and employ them as conductive substrates for self-supported electrocatalysts. The preparation of CNFs by the electrospinning way generally involves the following processes: The precursor nanofibers of CNFs are initially prepared using the electrospinning method. Subsequently, the precursor nanofibers underwent a pre-oxidative pretreatment in the air. Finally, the carbonization process is conducted under elevated temperatures in a protective atmosphere (e.g. N2). The phenomenon is followed by a phase of weight loss and shrinkage, which is accompanied by a transformation of the electrostatically spun polymer nanofibers into CNFs. As a consequence of the ongoing efforts of some researchers, the electrospinning technology has been able to be used to produce neatly aligned arrays of nanofibers as well as nanofibers with porous surfaces or two-component cross-sectional structures. When preparing carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts using the electrospinning method, different metal doping can be achieved by adding various metal sources to the precursor solution. For example, Co doping can be achieved by adding CoCl2 to the precursor solution. In addition, different carbonization atmospheres and times will also greatly affect the final catalyst. For example, an N2 or NH3 atmosphere can achieve elemental N doping, while carbonization in a Se-containing atmosphere can achieve selenide doping. In addition, the introduction of PTFE to the precursor solution is also a relatively well-developed method of preparing porous carbon nanofibers. Therefore, by different electrospinning precursor solutions or carbonization atmospheres, both can effectively modulate the final catalyst structure and ultimately improve its catalytic performances. There are many precursors for the preparation of CNFs by electrospinning way, and different precursors and various post-processing operations also can lead to forming different functional materials (Table 1 ). In these numerous precursors, the applied polyacrylonitrile (PAN) based materials are the most extensively researched due to the elevated carbon content of PAN and the advantages of structural diversity and controllability of the resulting carbons, which can be obtained by carbonation process. When the electrospinning solution is a pure polymer solution, the pure CNFs can be obtained after the calcination treatment with no other substances. Despite good flexibility and large specific surface area, such CNFs usually lack ideal electrocatalytic activity and therefore they require to be doped with other atoms to enhance their catalytic performances. Doping N atoms in CNFs is a common and straightforward strategy for enhancing catalytic performance, which can be directly synthesized using PAN with high nitrogen content as precursors. For instance, Li et al. [29] prepared Co3O4 NPs-modified NCNFs as efficient bi-functional oxygen electrocatalysts by electrospinning way, utilizing a homogeneous mixed solution of PAN and Co(OCA)2 in dimethylformamide (DMF) as the spinning solution. Furthermore, N doping can also be achieved through thermal treatment of the CNFs under an N2 or NH3 atmosphere. For example, Yan et al. [30] used electrospinning devices forming a carbon nanofiber network from a PAN precursor, which was then heat-treated under an N2 atmosphere to obtain the N-doped porous carbon nanofiber network (NPCNF) (Fig. 3 a), which possessed excellent bi-functional oxygen electrocatalytic properties, and liquid and quasi-solid ZABs assembled from the NPCNF exhibited excellent discharge voltage and discharge stability. Similarly, by adding metal salts to the polymer solution, metal-containing fabrics also can be obtained after electrospinning way, and CNFs materials containing metal actives can be prepared after calcination treatment. For example, Pan et al. [31] homogeneously dispersed equal amounts of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 in DMF and PAN, and then obtained self-supported Co/Zn-doped NCNFs by electrospinning way and thermal oxidation processes (Fig. 3b), and the liquid ZABs assembled from them also showed outstanding cycling stability and durability. In addition to the conventional electrospinning method, in order to cover a wider range of applications of electrospun nanofiber in various fields, some researchers have developed the coaxial electrospinning method to produce core-shell or hollow nanofiber with special structures and functions. For example, Wang et al. [32] have shown in experiments that coaxial electrospinning was a further development of conventional electrospinning, and it can provide more reaction sites and better contact between the reactants, which is an efficient way of optimizing the nanostructures. In the preparation of core-shell nanofibers using the coaxial electrostatic spinning method, the spinning solution of the core and shell materials needs to be dispensed in two different syringes. In a high-voltage electric field, the shell layer liquid is stretched by high frequency, and high-speed spraying will produce strong shear stress at the interface between the inner and outer layers of the solution. At this time, the core layer solution migrates coaxially along the shell layer under the action of shear stress, bending and flinging deformation and curing into ultrafine coaxial composite nanofibers. For example, by applying coaxial electrospinning, Meng et al. [33] synthesized the self-supported flexible bi-functional electrocatalysts (Fig. 3c), i.e., FeCoNi flexible carbon nanofibers (FeCoNi FCNFs) and so on. In addition to core-shell nanofibers, Janus and hollow nanofibers can also be produced using coaxial electrospinning. Among these, Janus fibers usually consist of two or more parts that are parallel and independent of each other on the micron or nanometer scale [34]. The formed unique asymmetry allows Janus structured fibers to be combined with materials with different surface activities to form novel surface structures that exhibit complex asymmetries and multi-functionality. Meanwhile, it should be noted that the structures described above do not exist in isolation, rather, CNFs-based self-supported electrocatalysts with composite structures can be obtained by certain methods. For example, Chen et al. [35] endowed Janus nanofibers with a unique core-shell hollow fiber structure by coaxial electrospinning and hydrothermal method and carbonization (Fig. 3d), the prepared unique Janus-like hollow structure resulting in excellent ORR and OER bi-functional catalytic performance for the self-supported catalysts exhibited in alkaline electrolytes. 2.2 Preparation of carbon fiber-based and carbon cloth-based self-supported electrocatalysts Unlike CNFs-based electrocatalysts, which are produced by electrospinning precursor solutions to create self-supported structures, CF and CC are typically grown in-situ on their surfaces using other in-situ growth methods for the synthesis of active materials. CF has shown great application prospects within the field of energy conversion technology due to its inherent advantages, such as the large specific surface area, controllable chemical composition, ease of processing, and a plethora of composite forms. Carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts with different structures can be designed and prepared by choosing different in-situ growth methods. For example, by controlling different precursor ratios, the construction of normal alloys or heterojunctions can be achieved. In addition, by electrochemical pretreatment (such as anodic oxidation or reduction treatment) of the substrate, the surface oxidation state and morphological structure can be modulated to form an oxidized or reduced layer with a surface enriched with active sites, which can greatly improve the catalytic activity of ORR and OER. The results of scanning electronic microscope (SEM) conducted by Shi et al. [36] revealed that the CC is comprised of thin, discrete, continuous, and smooth CF. The intact three-dimensional (3D) structure of CC on the micron scale can be found to be conducive to its excellent mechanical strength, as well as the presence of considerable void spaces, which facilitate ion penetration during the electrocatalytic process. Thus, CF and CC can be used as conducting substrates to prepare self-supported electrocatalysts. To enhance the catalytic performance of self-supported electrocatalysts with CF and CC as conductive substrates, some researchers have also devised a range of strategies for the in-situ growth of the catalysts on conducting substrates. The catalytic reactivity was modulated by controlling the elemental composition of the elements loaded on CF and CC substrates, the dispersion of the nano-catalysts, the size distribution, and the surface morphology [13]. Commonly in-situ growth methods include hydrothermal/solvent thermal, chemical vapor deposition, electrochemical deposition, template methods, etc. 2.2.1 Hydrothermal/solvent thermal Thus far, the hydrothermal/solvothermal method has been the most prevalent approach in the synthesis of catalysts due to its simple operation and low cost. In contrast to other synthetic strategies, this method allows the precise adjustment of several variables, including reaction temperature and time, solution pH, and precursor ratio, thereby facilitating the manipulation of the catalyst's structure and electronic state as well as enhancing the electrocatalytic performance [10]. As an illustrative example, Thangasamy et al. [37] directly grew ferrocene (Fc)-doped cobaltous sulfide (Co x S y ) nanostructures on an acid-pretreated CF (ACF) using a facile one-step solvent-thermal method (Fig. 4 a), which achieved simultaneous doping of Fe x S y and Fe x O y in Co x S y nanostructure. The structure can effectively promote ion and gas transfer between the active substance and ACF, resulting in an excellent OER performance. In addition, the method can also be used to build complex structures such as heterojunctions on conductive substrates. For instance, Yao et al. [38] prepared CoP-CoO p-p type heterojunction electrocatalysts on CC by using the solvothermal method (Fig. 4b), and it was shown that the heterojunctions can induce the rearrangement of electrons, and thus significantly increase OER activity by promoting OH− adsorption. In addition, based on the ability of the hydrothermal/solvothermal method to adjust the ratio of precursors, Teng et al. [39] used hydrothermal processes growing NiFe-LDH precursors with different Ni:Fe ratios on CC, and the electrochemical test results showed that the electrocatalytic performance was the best when the Ni:Fe molar ratio was 8:2 among these samples, which was able to better realize the optimal synergistic effect of the oxygen electrocatalytic activity between Ni and Fe. In conclusion, the applied hydrothermal/solvothermal methods can provide suitable conditions for the in-situ growth of active substances on CF and CC substrates and are widely employed in this field. However, the hydrothermal/solvent methods usually require high temperatures and pressures as well as a tightly sealed vessel to take place. Furthermore, this method cannot be used for the mass production of electrocatalysts because it usually uses many organic solvents, which can be very harmful to the environment. Therefore, it is necessary to improve the above shortcomings of hydrothermal/solvent thermal methods by some other means such as sacrificial solvent thermal methods [40], microwave-assisted solvent thermal methods [41], and so on. 2.2.2 Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) CVD is another manner of preparing self-supported electrocatalysts on CF and CC substrates. In the process, metal salts are first converted into gaseous precursors, which are then introduced into a reactor in a vacuum environment and deposited onto a conductive substrate by a chemical reaction process. CVD technology has been successfully applied to produce carbonaceous catalysts with high catalytic activity, including carbon nanotubes and graphene. This method has also proven to be an operative way for the construction of active components on electrocatalysts. It has gained increasing popularity in recent studies due to its significant advantages, including short synthesis time, ease of precise parameter control, and tunable microstructure [42]. For example, Lu et al. [43] designed and prepared a self-sustaining air electrode (Co-NCNT) comprising of Co NPs encapsulated in an array of N-doped CNTs and loaded onto a carbon fiber cloth through CVD. The SEM images revealed that the original morphological structure of CC was retained after CVD treatment, and the CF surface was massively and homogeneously modified by nanotubes (Fig. 4c). In conclusion, the CVD method is a simple and effective in-situ growth approach for achieving the loading of complex reactive substances on carbon fiber-based substrates. 2.2.3 Electrochemical deposition Electrochemical deposition is also a commonly used strategy to build self-supported electrocatalysts, which mainly involves depositing a conformal thin film or deposition layer on a conductive substrate via electrochemical techniques. The corresponding process is typically conducted within a conventional dual/triple-electrode system, and the nanocatalysts are selectively deposited onto the substrate at a certain applied potential, which is rather a method to simultaneously complete catalyst preparation and electrode preparation. Generally, these metals intended to be deposited can be used as the anode or the metal precursor solution, which can be mixed with the electrolyte solution and then electrolyzed by direct current. The synthesis conditions of this method are rather straightforward, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly. The formed self-supported electrocatalysts synthesized using this method exhibit good homogeneity and abundant active sites, rendering them highly suitable for mass production. For example, Liu et al. [44] deposited NiCo-LDH onto NiCo2S4/CC by electrochemical deposition in a typical three-electrode system (Fig. 4d), where the strong electronic coupling between NiCo-LDH and NiCo2S4 could significantly promote charge transfer and greatly enhance the reaction kinetics, which led to excellent electrocatalytic performance. In addition to using a single electrochemical deposition method, it is also possible to combine it with other methods to co-construct self-supported electrodes. One example is that Wang et al. [45] initially deposited the NiMo alloy on CC by electrochemical deposition, subsequently fabricating NiMo@CNTs-CC with a self-supported structure based on NiMo-CC via CVD. In addition to the above commonly applied methods, some researchers have also adopted other effective methods for loading some functional catalysts on CF and CC according to the materials’ properties. Recently, MOFs materials have been designed as sacrificial templates for generating MOFs-derived carbon by a simple pyrolysis method. For example, Muthurasu et al. [46] successfully grew MOF on CC-loaded FeCo-OH nanowire arrays by self-sacrificial process and then finally fabricated the hierarchical N-CNTs@MOF FeCo nano-arrays by an annealing process (Fig. 4e). 3 Catalytic mechanism and regulation of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts 3.1 Oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reaction mechanisms 3.1.1 Oxygen reduction reaction mechanism The ORR is a process of the electrochemical reaction in which oxygen accepts electrons and is reduced to the corresponding products, which is the cathodic reaction of fuel cells and metal-air batteries [47]. The reaction rate of the ORR will directly affect the battery's efficiency. The ORR reactions are primarily associated with processes such as multi-step electron gain-loss, as well as coupled proton migration. The mechanism of ORR is intricate and can be broadly categorized into the 4e− and 2e− reaction mechanisms. The 2e− reaction pathway generates peroxide intermediates, which not only greatly affect the ORR reaction rate but also seriously corrode the carbon-based catalysts due to their high oxidative properties. This can damage their structures and lead to the deactivation of the catalysts, which severely reduces the lifetime of rechargeable ZABs [48,49]. In contrast, the four-electron reaction pathway has no intermediates to form, resulting in high relative conversion efficiency, enabling the direct reduction of O2 to OH− or H2O. Consequently, in fuel cells and metal-air batteries, it is beneficial to facilitate the ORR reaction along a four-electron reaction pathway. The final result can be done either to enhance the energy conversion efficiency or voltage output or to preclude catalyst corrosion due to peroxides. The four-electron reaction pathway of ORR under various pH conditions is also different, and the specific process is as follows [22] (Fig. 5 a). Acidic conditions: (1) O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O Alkaline condition: (2) O2 + 2H2O + 4e− → 4OH− 3.1.2 Oxygen evolution reaction mechanism OER may appear to be the inverse of ORR, but in reality, this reaction involves a complicated pathway and has slow kinetics, which greatly limits its use in catalysis. In the ORR process, O2 is reduced to H2O or OH−. While in OER, H2O is oxidized to O2. The OER process mainly involves three main reaction intermediates (OH*, O*, and OOH*), and each reaction step also mainly involves the transfer of electrons. There are mainly two recognized OER mechanisms, namely the adsorbed oxygen mechanism (AEM) and the lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM). Since the LOM mechanism can directly bypass the process of OOH* formation in the AEM process and reduce the reaction energy barrier, many researchers are currently working on OER catalysts that follow the LOM mechanism [50]. The overall response of OER at different pH conditions is as follows [22,51] (Fig. 5b). Acidic conditions: (3) 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e− Alkaline condition: (4) 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e− 3.1.3 Bi-functional oxygen electrocatalyst For rechargeable ZABs, the slow kinetics of the ORR reaction during discharge and the OER reaction during charge is the major reason for their inability to be commercialized, so designing a bi-functional electrocatalyst that can simultaneously enhance the ORR/OER reaction rate is important to the vigorous development of rechargeable ZABs. Nørskov et al. analyzed the relationship between oxygen-binding energy and the theoretical activity at each step of ORR and OER [52]. It can be found that the metals located at the top of the volcano map are different for ORR and OER [53] (Fig. 5c). This suggests that it is not possible to achieve both optimal ORR and OER activities with the same monometallic catalyst. With the continuous exploration of researchers in recent years, many bi-functional oxygen electrocatalysts with excellent performances have emerged, and these catalysts mainly can be classified into two categories based on their compositions: Single-component and composite bi-functional catalysts, and all of them have their own advantages. Among them, single-component bi-functional catalysts are those in which the same active ingredient has both ORR and OER properties, and their chemical composition and synthesis process are simple and easy. On the other hand, composite bi-functional catalysts refer to the combination of different active substances with excellent ORR and OER properties to obtain good bi-functional catalytic activity through the synergistic effect of the two, which has a wider range of regulatory strategies and has gained the attention of many researchers [54]. For example, Zhao et al. [55] used Co-N-C as the ORR active site and NiFe LDHs as the OER active site, and rationally integrated the two by certain methods to obtain a composite catalyst with excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. In addition, Sabatier's principle posits that in multiphase catalysis, the adsorption of reactants by the catalyst should be neither too strong nor too weak, thus ensuring facile adsorption and rapid desorption of reactant intermediates [56]. On the other hand, the d-band theory suggests that the higher the center of the d-band (ε d), the higher the anti-bonding orbitals after interaction with the adsorbed species and the corresponding reduction in the filling of the antibonding orbitals, allowing for stronger adsorption [57]. Therefore, the adsorption strength can be modified by adjusting the ε d and shifting the catalyst towards the top of the volcano to enhance the accessibility of an oxygen electrocatalyst with optimal performance. Thus, the construction and preparation of the above-mentioned efficient bi-functional catalysts have generally been achieved by some researchers using strategies such as cationic and anionic doping as well as related modulation strategies [58–60]. For the ORR reaction, it mainly involves the conversion of O2*→OOH*→O*→OH*. O2* is the reactant of the reaction and requires good adsorption and low energy barriers for subsequent protonation reactions. Whereas OH* is the product of the final step of the reaction and requires a weaker binding strength for its easy detachment. On the contrary, for the OER reaction, it mainly involves the conversion of OH*→O*→OOH*→O2*. O2* also is the product of its final step and requires a weak binding strength to facilitate its stripping. Therefore, a bi-functional catalyst with excellent performance needs to have the ability to balance the adsorption behavior of O2*/OH* and to effectively promote the adsorption/desorption of various intermediate products. 3.2 Mechanisms for regulating ORR and OER activity in carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts Typically, materials comprising pure carbon do not have significant catalytic effects on the ORR/OER reaction, so it is inevitable to strengthen the catalytic capacity of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts by direct in-situ growth on the carbon fiber-based substrates or doping some atoms, thereby modifying the electronic structure or creating vacancies and defects. In terms of the modulation mechanism, self-supported structure catalysts are similar to conventional powder catalysts in that the catalytic performance can be modulated by components, structure, size, and surface remodeling. However, due to the presence of conductive substrates in self-supported structures, self-supported structure catalysts can also improve the overall catalytic performance by changing the conductivity or hydrophilicity of the conductive substrates. In addition, the in-situ growth process of different actives and the interaction between the actives and the conductive substrate can also have a modulating effect on the catalytic performances. By rationally regulating the apparent morphology and internal structure of self-supported electrodes, it is possible to make their surfaces more susceptible to surface hydrophilic/gas-phobic engineering, which can expand the contact area between the electrolyte and the active sites and accelerate the desorption of the bubble products, thus facilitating charge and ion transfer [61]. Currently, researchers regulate the electronic and structure-induced effects by modulating the size effect [62,63], defect effect [64–66], strain effect [67], interfacial effect [68], etc. (Fig. 6 ), which in turn improves the intrinsic activity and electrochemical catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts and constructs highly active and durable electrode materials. 3.2.1 Size effect modulation of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts When preparing self-supported electrocatalysts using carbon fiber-based materials as conductive substrates, to fully utilize the merit such as a large specific surface area, it is usually necessary to further increase the loading of active materials on the substrate by reducing the catalyst size [69] (Fig. 7 a). Some researchers have utilized the principle of the size effect for many decades to modify the catalytic performance of catalysts, which primarily refers to the enhancement of catalyst activity due to the reduced size. The main reason is that the decrease in the size of metal NPs leads to an increase in the number of unsaturated coordination sites of metal atoms on their surfaces and enlarges the energy level dispersion and the band gap of the front orbitals, which can effectively improve the catalytic efficiency of metal nanocatalysts [70,71]. In addition, as the size of nanoparticles decreases, higher atomic utilization can be obtained in theory. Therefore, when the size of metal particles is reduced to the nanoscale, both their geometrical and electronic characteristics can be changed to further enhance the electrocatalytic effect. This strategy has inspired the development and application of nanoscale catalysts. From the point of view of the altered geometrical characteristics of the metal particles, as the size of the metal particles decreases, the low-coordinated atoms are progressively exposed and their proportion gradually increases, which will have a modulating effect on the structure and proportion of the active center of the catalytic materials [72]. In addition, a strong coupling structure can be formed between the carbon fiber substrates and the catalytically active substances, which can not only further improve the intrinsic catalytic activity of the loaded nanomaterials but also increase the electrical conductivity of the catalysts due to the synergistic effect of the hybrid nanostructures, thus obtaining the desired electrocatalytic performance [73]. For example, Zhu et al. [74] loaded hollow carbon nano-arrays with tiny Co NPs (HCA-Co) on CC. The XRD analyses demonstrated that the Co NPs in the samples produced when the Co2+ concentration in the precursor solution was 0.02 mmol, with smaller sizes and higher ratios of Co-N and pyridinium-N to graphite-N. The tests suggest that samples with smaller Co NPs had more catalytic reaction sites and better electrocatalytic performance. Similarly, Ma et al. [75] utilized ZnCo-ZIFs as a feedstock, successfully developing highly dispersed (Zn) Co-NCF freestanding catalysts based on CF. The tested TEM showed that the size of Co NPs in CF was only around 5 nm (Fig. 7b). This ultra-fine distribution of Co species could well control the specific surface area and availability of catalytically active sites in the prepared (Zn) Co-NCF, which could greatly promote its rapid interfacial electron transfer and enhance the ORR/OER catalytic activity. Many relevant studies have shown that exploiting size effects can also modify the surface properties of metallic nanoparticles and conducting substrates [76,77] and modulate the intrinsic activity of the catalyst by affecting intermediate adsorption and reaction pathways. For example, Zhang et al. [78] achieved the co-doping of Co5.47N particles of about 100 nm in size and Fe single atoms on a hollow carbon nanofiber film with a specific surface area of about 385.36 m2/g. The high specific surface area is conducive to the interaction of different active sites, which significantly accelerates the mass transfer. The corresponding density functional theory (DFT) calculations show that the OER activity mainly originates from the Co sites and the ORR activity from the Fe sites. At the same time, the proton and charge transfer between N and metal atoms could further reduce the reaction potential barrier, thus exhibiting excellent bi-functional catalytic activity. Generally, the larger the particle size is, the higher the coordination number of the surface atoms is. Thus the OH* adsorption energy can be increased by increasing the amount of nearest neighbor coordination sites [79]. However, when the particle size is less than a few nanometers, there is a relaxation effect that reduces the adsorption energy. Therefore, a more scientific understanding of the size effect of catalysts is needed in order to design some functional electrocatalysts in the optimal particle size range and load them onto carbon fiber-based substrates with a large specific surface area to maximize their catalytic performances. 3.2.2 Defect effect modulation of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts Defect effects are also a significant strategy for modulating the catalytic performance of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts by changing the electronic and geometric structures of the catalysts. In addition, this strategy can also possibly create additional active sites and tune the surface charge transfer properties. There are many types of defects in materials with point defects being the most studied and can be further classified based on their locations and compositions into vacancy defects, un-doped defective carbon and heteroatom doping defects [80]. The formation of vacancy defects can also create unsaturated coordination sites, thus modulating adsorption energy. Since the formation energy of oxygen vacancies is very low and the physicochemical properties of oxides (e.g. surface electronic properties and bandgap states) can change with the presence of oxygen vacancies [81], many researchers have modulated the final catalytic performance by adjusting the oxygen vacancy content. For example, Ji et al. [82] achieved the modulation of oxygen vacancies in embedded hollow Co3O4 nanoparticles by modulating the Kirkendall effect at the nanoscale. Furthermore, the related electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements showed that the ESR reached the highest value at an oxidation time of 60 min, indicating that a large number of oxygen vacancies existed at this time. The related X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) further demonstrated that the highest oxygen vacancy content of 21.8% could be obtained when oxidized for 60 min among these samples (Fig. 7c). Additionally, electrochemical tests also showed that the samples with high oxygen vacancy content had better bi-functional catalytic activity when compared with other samples. Oxygen vacancy modulation can also be achieved by doping the substrate with specific elements in addition to the Kirkendall effect. Based on these discussions, Gultom et al. [83] prepared La-doped Co3O4 by electrochemical deposition at room temperature using CC as a substrate. The tested results showed that doping La in the Co3O4 matrix lattice could regulate the number of oxygen vacancies. The EPR analysis demonstrated a gradual increase in peak intensity with the increase of La doping concentration, indicating that the number of oxygen vacancies increased with La content, and the ORR/OER performance was best when the La doping concentration was 0.025 M. Moreover, theoretical calculations based on the corresponding DFT have demonstrated that the presence of oxygen vacancies plays an important role in enhancing electrical conductivity, thereby facilitating the process of charge transfer [84]. Previous studies have found that edge sites readily act on C=O and C–OH groups. In addition, the armchair and serrated active sites can modify the local coordination environment for high-catalytic activity [80]. On this basis, Wang et al. [85] designed a miniature electrochemical testing system using highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) as a working electrode (Fig. 7d). They collected electrochemical signals at different locations and demonstrated that carbon located at the edge is more active than that of carbon located at the basal surface. Based on these findings, some researchers have been working on the preparation of metal-free carbon materials with more intrinsic defects to improve catalytic activity. Intrinsic defects can generally be created by reducing the size of the carbon or creating defects during the synthesis process. For example, Liu et al. [86] successfully achieved in situ exfoliation of CF surface edge/defect O-rich and O-doped graphene by using Ar plasma treatment of CC during the synthesis process, and the corresponding DFT calculations also showed that the defective graphene structure with C-OOH species has excellent electrocatalytic properties. The enhancement of catalytic activity is due to the synergistic effect of defects and O-doping induced by argon plasma treatment. Besides the various common defect effect modulations mentioned above, distortions and grain boundaries (GB) are important defect types that disrupt atomic periodicity, finally leading to inhomogeneous electron distribution. Grain boundaries (GB) can change not only the crystallinity of the crystal but also the strain distribution, coordination number, and defect density, leading to changes in the electronic structure. For example, Ye et al. [87] crystallized arrays of CoOOH nanosheets with low crystallinity and loaded onto CC as self-supported electrodes. The tested fast Fourier transform (FFT) spectra showed that the catalyst was composed of a group of grains with different orientations and that there were many grain boundaries between these grains (Fig. 7e), and the EPR spectra also indicated the presence of oxygen vacancies. Thanks to the oxygen vacancies at the grain boundaries and the liganded unsaturated Co sites, the prepared LC-CoOOH NAs exhibited excellent oxygen electrocatalytic activity. In summary, in carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts, the defect effect is mainly used to optimize the catalytic activity of the carbon fiber-based substrates by regulating the corresponding electronic structure and density distribution around the carbon atoms. The presence of defect sites also can cause local strains, which can activate the carbon atoms around the defect sites, decrease the activation energy of the reaction, and finally improve the catalytic efficiency. In addition, by constructing different types of defects, the targeted regulation of the different reaction stages in the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction process is possible. Therefore, more advanced characterization techniques are needed to characterize the defect structures (such as ESR, photoacoustic spectroscopy (PAS), spherical aberration corrected transmission electron microscope (ACTEM), etc.), so that some researchers can obtain more accurate information about the defect structures, conduct more in-depth investigations on the mechanism of defects and the relationship between the defect structures and catalytic efficiencies. 3.2.3 Interfacial effect modulation of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts An interface is conventionally understood as a boundary between two distinct components. The interfacial effect can be described as follows: When an interface is formed between two different types of active materials, the interface may exhibit a higher level of active centers than that of a single component due to electronic interactions or synergistic effects [88]. When two components directly contact to form an interface, some differences in geometry, disorder, and Fermi energy levels will trigger interfacial effects at the interfaces. Furthermore, interfacial engineering by combining some functional catalysts with complementary activities can also break the scalar relationship, thus improving the catalytic efficiency [89]. There are three main types of interfaces in carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts: (1) the internal interface of the electrocatalyst, (2) the carbon fiber-based conductive substrate/catalyst interface, and (3) the electrolyte/self-supported catalyst interface. Therefore, the catalytic performance of self-supported electrocatalysts can also be effectively improved by controlling these interfaces [90]. The modulation of the internal interface of the electrocatalyst mainly refers to the construction of heterogeneous structures on carbon fiber-based substrates. The construction of heterojunctions can regulate the electronic configuration, change the electron distribution between the two phases, and increase the number of active sites, which can change the Gibbs free energy of the active intermediates in the electrochemical reaction and improve the catalytic efficiency to a certain degree [91,92]. Under interfacial interaction, some transition metal compound-based heterostructured catalysts exhibit excellent ORR/OER catalytic activities comparable to those of noble metal-based catalysts. For example, Zhang et al. [93] designed and prepared a 3D needle-like Ru-doped Ni/Co oxide array based on a CC substrate. The formation of a NiO/Co3O4 heterostructure and Ru doping (optimal doping ratio of 2%) was demonstrated by electronic detection and elemental analysis (Fig. 8 a), which resulted in the modulation of the overall electronic energy states of the catalysts. In turn, this result also increased the activation energy, conductivity and electrochemically active surface area of the catalysts, which brought the excellent ORR/OER/HER catalytic activity. The rest of the detailed description of heterojunctions will be covered in Section 4.3.2 below. The performance and catalytic efficiency of electrocatalysts are also largely influenced by the interface between them and the conducting substrate. Therefore, an effective catalytic interface can be established between the carbon fiber-based substrates and the catalytically active material through strong metal carrier interaction (SMSI). In terms of stability, in the process of electrocatalytic reaction, the catalyst is prone to become agglomerated and dissolved through the SMSI between the metal and the substrate also forms a strong bond to improve its stability. The existence of the interface can prevent the sintering and oxidation of the metal particles under the relatively high over-voltage, thus greatly reducing the poisoning of the catalyst. Carbon fiber-based materials are widely used as support materials due to excellent electrical conductivity, large specific surface area, outstanding chemical stability, and adjustable pore structure. When monometallic atoms are grown in situ on carbon fiber-based carriers, the metal-carbon interface can act as an ORR/OER active site. For instance, Han et al. [94] grew Co monoatomic in situ on the N-doped porous carbon nanofibers, wherein the bi-functional electrocatalytic activity was markedly augmented by the presence of atomically dispersed Co-N4 sites. In addition to the interfacial effect occurring between the monometallic atoms and the carbon fiber-based carriers, the SMSI between the alloy and the carbon fiber-based carriers also substantially improves the catalytic performance of the catalysts. For instance, Niu et al. [95] successfully anchored NiFe NPs on the bamboo rod-derived N-doped carbon fibers (NiFe@N-CFs). The SMSI and synergistic effects between the NiFe NPs and the N-doped carbon resulted in the prepared NiFe@N-CFs exhibiting excellent catalytic activity and stability in alkaline media (Fig. 8b). The quasi-solid ZABs assembled by the NiFe@N-CFs as flexible self-supported air cathodes also exhibited high round-trip efficiency and mechanical stability. In addition to the above, some researchers have also constructed self-supported air cathodes with efficient ORR/OER reaction rates by loading active substances at the asymmetric interface between the hydrophobic and hydrophilic sides [96]. For example, Liu et al. [97] introduced an asymmetric interface of the immiscible toluene-water binary phase at the air cathode and placed carbon paper at this asymmetric interface. Then bimetallic NiFe-oxides were in-situ grew on the side of the carbon paper in contact with the aqueous solution by co-precipitation method, which showed that this asymmetric interface could significantly improve the utilization efficiency of the catalyst. Finally, the ZABs assembled also showed excellent cycling stability. In conclusion, the modulation of interfacial effects in carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts mainly includes the interfaces between metal and metal, metal and the related compounds, or between metal and carbon fiber-based conductive substrates. All these interfaces can effectively modulate the electronic structure, work function, and other intrinsic activities of these functional catalysts through electronic, geometrical, coordination, synergistic, and domain-limiting effects, thus significantly enhancing their electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. 3.2.4 Strain effect modulation of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts In addition to the conventional strategies of defect, shape/size modulation, and heterostructure formation, lattice strain engineering is an emerging approach that can modulate the electronic and geometrical configurations of metal sites. Lattice strain is caused by changes in atom-to-atom bond lengths or lattice dislocations, which are also known as strain effects. The strain effects can be classified into two types: compressive and tensile strain. Both types of strain can be used to adjust the electronic structure of the surface by altering the dispersion of the surface atoms and their bond lengths, thus optimizing the catalytic performance. The d-band model suggests that the surface adsorption energy and the intermediate activation potential barrier of a strained catalyst mainly depend on the position of ε d. The previous experimental and theoretical studies of trends in adsorption and desorption behavior of ε d on Ru (0001) steps are summarized below (Fig. 8c). The tensile strain facilitates the upward movement of the ε d and antibonding d-states, thereby greatly enhancing catalyst/adsorbate interactions. Conversely, compressive strain broadens the ε d, resulting in an increased occupation of the antibonding orbitals and a weakening of the adsorption strength of the reactive intermediates [56,98]. According to the different methods of introducing lattice strains, the strains can be classified into intrinsic and artificial strains. Intrinsic strain is an inherent property that arises spontaneously during catalyst synthesis [67]. The intrinsic strain is generally achieved by fine-tuning the lattice spacing to optimize the surface geometry and electronic structure to achieve unique catalytic activity, which can be achieved in several ways: heteroatom doping [99], heterostructures [100], epitaxial growth [101], de-alloying, vacancy defects [102], and morphology/size effects. Recently, Poudel et al. [103] used carbon fiber cloth as a substrate, alloyed Fe with Ni and confined it in a pyridine N-rich sp 2 carbon skeleton, and modulated the lattice strain in the alloy by adjusting the content of materials (Fig. 8d), which in turn altered the intrinsic activity, resulting in an OER overpotential of 173 mV and an ORR half-wave potential of 0.87 V. In addition, to change the strain relaxation and catalytic performance degradation caused by the structural instability, Li et al. [104] proposed to use a small amount of Cu as a dopant to regulate the two-phase ratio of CoF2-CoS2, which in turn regulates the lattice strain at the interface of the two phases and avoids the phenomenon of strain relaxation, to make the optimal adsorption energy of ORR/OER intermediates, thus obtaining the self-supported catalysts with excellent ORR/OER catalytic performance. Recently, Li et al. [105] successfully grew metal oxide nanoparticles with a hollow structure on CNFs by a simple electrostatic spinning-carbonation-Kirkendall oxidation process. It was found that the lattice strain induced by the Kirkendall effect could be controlled by adjusting the proportion of metal precursors, and tensile lattice strains with different degrees (1.8%, 2.0%, and 2.2%) occurred in transition metal oxides, such as Co3O4, Fe2O3, and NiO, with the strain Co3O4 (1.8%) having the best ORR/OER performance. DFT calculations showed that the lattice strain of Co3O4 induced a downward shift of the Fermi energy level, which promoted the movement of electrons from the Co 3d orbitals to the O 2p band, thus reducing the binding energy and improving the oxygen electrocatalytic activity. Through the above discussions of the regulatory mechanisms of carbon fiber based-self-supported electrocatalysts, it is not difficult to find that the various regulatory mechanisms mentioned above do not exist independently, and most of them can be achieved by in-situ growth of heteroatoms or metal atoms and their compounds on carbon fiber-based substrates. Therefore, in order to achieve a better catalytic effect of these catalysts, some researchers usually combine the above regulatory mechanisms through atomic doping engineering to achieve some changes in the electronic structure and the adsorption energy of the intermediates. Thus, the catalytic performance of the carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts can be regulated through the strain effect modulation. 4 Modification of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts by atomic doping engineering Although the structure of the carbon fiber-based material itself has been able to satisfy the need for electron transport, it still is difficult to provide the necessary active sites for all electrocatalytic reactions [106]. Based on the above discussion of the different regulatory mechanisms of carbon-based self-supported electrocatalysts, some researchers have generally improved the catalytic performance of carbon fiber-based substrates by growing other elements on them in situ. There are two general methods of doping. (1) In-situ doping, which is the carbonization of precursors with other elements and carbon sources after they have been mixed, or the direct carbonization of carbon precursors with other elements, which allows other atoms to be introduced into the layered graphite crystals during the synthesis of the carbonaceous material for doping modification. (2) Post-doping, that is, the carbon fiber-based material in the atmosphere containing the necessary elements (such as NH3, H2, etc.) after high-temperature treatment so that other atoms can replace the carbon atoms in the multi-layered graphite crystals in the carbon-containing material as a way to achieve the doping purpose. Currently, it is common for some researchers to dope carbon fiber-based substrates with hetero-atoms or transition metals and their compounds to improve their catalytic properties. 4.1 Heteroatom doping When heteroatoms of different sizes and electronegativities (e.g. S, N, B, P, F, etc.) are introduced into the carbon fiber-based matrix by pyrolysis, high-temperature etching, etc., as shown in Fig. 9 (a) [107], the redistribution and realignment of charge states and spin states among the surrounding carbon atoms can be induced to change their electronic structures and produce synergistic effects [108]. This affects the adsorption/desorption energies of the intermediates (O*, OH*, and OOH*), resulting in significant changes in the properties of the carbon-based fiber compared to the pristine materials and achieving highly efficient bi-functional catalytic activity for ORR/OER [109]. 4.1.1 N-atom doping Among the heteroatom-doped carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts, N doping has been the most studied. The doping of carbon materials with N atoms and the improvement of their ORR/OER catalytic performance when compared to other heteroatoms are driven by the following factors. (1) The electronegativity of N atoms (3.04) is higher than that of C atoms (2.55). Therefore, the introduction of N atoms into a carbon-based system will increase the density of positive charges on adjacent C atoms. (2) The radii of the two structures are comparable, thus ensuring an optimal alignment between the lattices to a certain extent. (3) N has one more electron than C, allowing it to facilitate electron-demanding reactions such as ORR. (4) The combination of N and C is capable of generating outer arc-pair electrons which are subsequently converted into additional defects, thereby increasing the number of active sites [110]. (5) In comparison to other heteroatoms, N-doped C materials are synthesized by a greater variety of methods, including pyrolysis [22], hydrothermal carbonization [111], chemical vapor deposition [112], ball milling [113] and plasma treatments [114], and these methods can be employed to dope N into C materials. In 2016, Yang et al. [115] first reported the bi-functional catalytic mechanism of N-doped carbon materials, where the electron-donating graphite-N is the active site of ORR, while the electron-absorbing pyridine-N is responsible for the OER, which demonstrated the realization of bi-functional properties of non-metallic carbon catalysts. In addition, the researchers found that different N species have different catalytic abilities. For instance, by pyrolysis of carbon black and urea, Liu et al. [116] prepared a series of N-doped carbons. The results indicated that the catalytic activity of the N species in the carbons followed a particular order: Pyridine-N > Pyrrole-N > Graphite-N > Oxide-N. Thus, some researchers seek to enhance the catalytic performance of N-doped carbon materials by increasing the pyridine-N content. For instance, Li et al. [117] constructed lignin-based flexible N-doped CNFs films as self-supported electrodes with multiple hollow channels and enriched mesoporous structures by electrospinning way and subsequent annealing processes. Analytical tests demonstrated that this unique porous/channel structure and rapid ion-electron transfer could effectively accelerate the reaction kinetics, and its ORR activity is mainly derived from graphitic-N and pyridine-N, while its OER activity is mainly derived from pyridine-N. The efficient expression of the graphite-N/pyridine-N active sites, coupled with the synergistic effect between the two kinds of materials, resulted in the self-supported films exhibiting excellent ORR/OER catalytic activity (Fig. 9b). Furthermore, the enhancement of N-doped C material defect density by suitable methodologies can also result in the significant improvement of their electrocatalytic performance. For example, Hang et al. [118] successfully prepared a defect-enriched and pyridine-N-dominated bi-functional electrocatalyst (DN-CP@G) with a core-shell structure. The prepared catalyst exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability in an alkaline medium. The theoretical studies indicated that the excellent electrocatalytic activity of DN-CP@G could be attributed to the high content of pyridine-N dopant introduced abundant defect sites and charge densities, resulting in excellent electrocatalytic activity (Fig. 9c). On the other hand, Pendashteh et al. [119] employed a hydrothermal method to regulate the N doping and defect density on the carbon nanotube fiber fabrics. The result brought optimized samples with a high concentration of pyridine-N and sp 3 carbon, which demonstrated excellent ORR/OER bi-functional catalytic activity and the capacity to directly serve as a self-supported air cathode to assemble rechargeable ZABs. Although N-atom doping can augment the oxygen electrocatalytic performance of carbon fiber-based substrates, in current practical studies, some researchers generally use N-doped carbon materials as carriers to load other heteroatoms or metal atoms. This phenomenon is mainly due to the existence of five available valence electrons in the N atom, which can enable the formation of strong covalent bonds and good SMSI, thus significantly enhancing the catalyst's performance. 4.1.2 Heteroatom co-doping Heteroatom doping can readily alter surface chemistry and modulate the electron distribution of carbon materials. This modification approach has been identified as an efficient strategy for enhancing the catalytic properties of carbon materials [120]. The co-doping of multiple heteroatoms onto the carbon fiber-based substrate not only can increase its surface area and improve the porosity and redox activity but also enhance the stability when compared to mono-doping with N atoms. Consequently, co-doping of N atoms with other heteroatoms can further improve the catalytic efficiency of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts through the introduction of more reactive centers. To date, many researchers have investigated the double doping of B, S, P, F, Cl, and N or even the co-doping system, such as N-P-S, N-B-F, etc. Of the many heteroatoms, S (2.58) and C (2.55) atoms have similar electronegativity, so the transfer of charge between them is negligible [121]. Since N and S have a similar electronic structure and atomic radius as the C atom but dissimilar electronegativity and electron affinity potentials from C, which results in a change of charge redistribution and spin state on the sp 2 carbon planes of the catalysts as they enter into the carbon nanomaterials and then promote the adsorption and desorption of intermediates, thus facilitating the reaction [122]. For example, Rao et al. [123] demonstrated that S, N co-doping has appropriate oxygen adsorption energy and more excellent ORR and OER activities compared with those of S or N mono-doping through mechanistic studies (Fig. 9d).Consequently, many researchers have begun to study N, S co-doped carbon materials with excellent ORR/OER bi-functional catalytic activity. For example, Zhao et al. [124] proved the successful co-doping of S, N onto CC substrates through an integrated in-situ weaving and surface engineering approach, resulting in the remarkable bi-functional catalytic properties observed in Fig. 9(e). Additionally, their findings highlighted the significant potential of CC as a low-cost and robust conductive substrate for rechargeable ZABs. In addition to the CC substrate, the interaction between the carbon fiber paper (CFP) and the active substance also benefits the improvement of catalytic performance. For instance, Cheng et al. [125] directly grew microporous-dominated N/S co-doped carbon films on conductive CFP as self-supported air electrodes. The interactions between the films and the CFP resulted in the prepared CFP@NSC exhibiting high catalytic activity for ORR/OER with good stability. Due to the strong interaction between NSC and CFP, it can maximize the exposure of the active site and also increase the electron transfer between the conducting substrate and active materials, the prepared CFP@NSC exhibited high catalytic activity for both ORR/OER. In addition to being co-doped with S atoms, atom N can also be combined with other non-metallic elements (P, O, F, etc.), thereby enhancing the oxygen electrocatalytic activity of carbon fiber-based matrix. For instance, Qiang et al. [126] synthesized N-doped porous CNFs with tunable oxygen species (NPCNF-O). The large specific surface area and the synergistic effect of N and O co-doping enabled the prepared NPCNF-O to exhibit excellent ORR and OER activities. Furthermore, the catalysts also demonstrated excellent stability in alkaline electrolytes (Fig. 9f). Meanwhile, the corresponding DFT calculations showed that O2*→OOH* was the reaction’s RDS of ORR, while the OER RDS was OH*→O*. Furthermore, the co-doping of three or more heteroatoms can also enhance the catalytic performance by modulating the local electronic structure of the carbon atoms, optimizing intermediate adsorption and providing more active sites [127]. To provide an illustrative example, Li et al. [128] synthesized a novel self-supported metal-free carbon-based bi-functional electrocatalyst for the first time with homogeneous multiple heteroatoms (N, F, S) doping and a large specific surface area. The surface area of the prepared NFS-CNF is considerable, and the synergistic effect of its multifaceted doped heteroatom and micro-media-pore porous carbon structure results in excellent bi-functional electrocatalytic properties and durability in alkaline media. The corresponding DFT calculations also showed that the bandgap of the carbon material decreased after heteroatom doping, which made the electron leaps easier. The result also demonstrated that this heteroatom doping can greatly reduce the adsorption energy of oxygen on the carbon material, thus accelerating the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction. In summary, whether the N atoms are doped alone or co-doped with S, P, B, and other heteroatoms due to the differences between these atoms and carbon atoms in terms of atomic size, electronegativity and bonding state, their doping in the carbon skeleton can produce perturbations in the carbon system. The reasons will change the charge distribution or atomic spin density of the carbon fiber-based substrates and further significantly improve its hydrophilicity, its contact interface with the electrolyte, and its conductivity to facilitate the adsorption and desorption of the reaction intermediates, which ultimately enhance the catalytic efficiency the carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts. 4.2 Single-metal and their compounds doping In addition to heteroatom doping, transition metal single atoms and their compounds have also been extensively investigated for their excellent electrocatalytic properties. Researchers have conducted extensive studies on the performance optimization of transition metal-doped carbon fiber-based electrocatalysts. 4.2.1 Single-metal atoms doping Single-atomic materials of non-precious metals have garnered considerable interest in the field of electrocatalysis because of their inherent benefits, such as cheaper raw materials, smaller sizes, and higher atom utilization. However, the single-metal atoms can tend to agglomerate and destroy catalytic active sites during preparation and measurement [129], so they must be loaded on suitable substrates to prevent them from aggregating. Furthermore, strong interactions between carriers and individual metal atoms can modulate the electronic structure of the metal elements and greatly improve the stability of the catalysts, leading to outstanding reactivity and selectivity. Therefore, the loading of monometallic atoms on carbon fiber-based carriers has some advantages of large atomic utilization, unique electronic structure, and significant metal-carrier interactions [130]. Thus, has become a hot spot in the field of oxygen electrocatalysis in recent years. In single-metal atom doping, carbon matrix-supported M−N x (M is a transition metal) type catalysts have become a research focus for catalysis due to the advantages of porphyrin-like structure with N-coordinated metal active centers as well as the near 100% metal atom utilization and abundant catalytic active sites [131]. The related DFT calculations also indicate that the M−N−C structure is capable of effectively activating linear O2 molecules through non-covalent interactions, thus effectively overlapping the metal 3d orbitals with the O 2p orbitals [132]. Furthermore, the transfer of electrons between N atoms with strong electronegativity and metal atoms can alter the configuration of electrons around the metal atom. The chemical bond formed between N atoms and metal atoms provides support and stability for the metal atoms while also regulating the electronic structure of the metal or C atoms. The structure can effectively optimize the adsorption and desorption energies of the intermediates, thereby improving the catalytic activity [133] and benefiting from the strong coordination between the transition metal and N atoms. More importantly, the formed M−N−C monatomic catalyst is effectively resistant to acid etching and thermal migration, making it a promising bi-functional catalyst. As everyone knows, the FeN x /C catalysts obtained by pyrolysis at high temperatures have long been regarded as one of the best electrocatalysts on a carbon basis. The corresponding DFT calculations have demonstrated that a strong coupling can be obtained between the Fe-N4 ligands, which facilitates the oxidation and reduction of oxygen molecules [134]. For instance, Yang et al. [135] prepared a self-supported flexible CF film with a hierarchical nanoporous structure through an electrostatic spinning and pyrolysis process. The prepared membrane contained highly exposed Fe-N4/C active sites, which enabled the Fe/SNCFs-NH3 catalyst to exhibit excellent ORR/OER activity (Fig. 10 a). When the carbon carriers are also loaded with other heteroatoms (e.g., S, P, etc.), the long-range interactions of these heteroatoms can tailor the local electronic structure of the Fe-N4/C portion and the carbon substrate, thus facilitating the adsorption and conversion of ORR and/or OER intermediates at a more favorable reaction potential. For example, Yang et al. [136] prepared a self-supporting hierarchical porous CNFs film with a large specific surface area via a novel ZnS-assisted synthesis route (Fig. 10b). The enhancement of its ORR/OER activity mainly originates from the electronic structure of the S-doped modulated Fe-N4/C x sites, the enhanced three-phase reactive interfaces and the high exposure of Fe-N4/C x sites in the outer surface area of the hierarchical macro/meso/micropores. In addition to its excellent catalytic properties under alkaline conditions, the Fe-N-C structure also exhibits outstanding stability in acidic electrolytes benefiting from the good stability of the carbon fiber-based supports. For example, Li et al. [137] successfully prepared self-supported ORR catalytic fabrics consisting of N, Fe co-doped CNFs and graphene by electrospinning way, which showed similar levels of catalytic activity in alkaline and acidic environments with excellent stability and methanol tolerance of N/Fe-CG compared to commercial Pt/C. Its stability and catalytic activity are mainly derived from the synergistic effect of N and Fe. However, a major risk of Fe-based catalysts is their susceptibility to the formation of Fenton reagents via the reaction of H2O2 with FeII/FeIII, and this can lead to serious performance degradation or even failure of fuel cells or metal-air batteries. For this reason, the preparation of M−N−C catalysts with Co, Mn, or Cu as M has recently received great attention [138,139]. Co-based catalysts have attracted a lot of attention due to their abundance, ease of preparation and good bi-functional activity. Specifically, the Co-N-C portion displayed a greater half-wave potential and current density during the ORR processthan commercial Pt/Ccatalysts [140]. Additionally, the catalyst's OER activity and long-term stabilitywere exceptional, indicating that it could be a useful catalyst for bi-functional oxygen electrocatalysis [141]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a new type of porous materials consisting of metal ions/cluster coordination bonds linked to organic ligands with high crystallinity and long-range ordering [142]. The M−N−C materials derived from them have been widely used in bi-functional catalysts and have achieved good performance due to their high specific surface area, tunable pore sizes and topologies, well-defined metal nodes, tunable chemical compositions, and surface functionalities [143]. ZIF-67, as an important representative of MOFs, is often used as a key precursor in the Co-doping process [144]. During high-temperature pyrolysis, the ZIF-67 precursor can be converted into transition metal Co sites, allowing it to catalyze electrochemical reactions effectively. For example, Ji et al. [145] obtained the self-supported electrodes with bi-functional catalytic activity by pyrolyzing the ZIF-67 precursor and loading it onto CNFs substrates (Fig. 10c), which exhibited a reversible oxygen overpotential of 0.7 V and a high degree of stability. The Co ions-N ligand units in the ZIFs can be reduced in-situ during the pyrolysis process, resulting in the formation of atomically dispersed Co-N sites, and the DFT calculations also showed that Co had a lower OH* hydrogenation energy barrier when the prepared material was in monoatomic form than in cluster form. The tested result can greatly improve the ORR/OER reaction rate. On the other hand, Meng et al. [146] successfully developed a 3D self-supported bi-functional oxygen electrode (Co4N/CNW/CC) for the first time by one-step carbonization of ZIF-67 strands on a polypyrrole nanofiber network based on CC under N2 atmosphere (Fig. 10d). The prepared self-supported flexible bi-functional oxygen electrode exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity and stability for both OER and ORR. The catalytic performance of Co-N-C structures can also be enhanced by controlling the structure and morphology of the N-C component. For example, Xia et al. [147] designed and prepared the self-supported membranes (Co/CNWs/CNFs) consisting of graded Co/CNFs by generating a unique graded structure that can expose more Co-N-C active sites and facilitate the mass diffusion and electron transfer processes, and when used as self-supported air electrodes in rechargeable ZABs achieved excellent cycling stability. Recently, Lu et al. [148] successfully constructed flexible self-supported bifunctional oxygen electrodes (CNT@Co-CNFF50-900) with a unique conductive “bridge” structure between carbon fibers with a reactive center of Co-N/C@pyridine N/C@CNTs by electrospinning way with the addition of an appropriate amount of F127 surfactant. Among them, the outer layer of Co NPs had an obvious graphite-carbon layer, and this high degree of graphitization can effectively enhance the corrosion resistance and electrical conductivity of the carbon fiber substrate. Under the combined effect of this highly graphitized carbon fiber substrate and the “π–π” bonding, the freestanding CNT@Co-CNFF50-900 electrode exhibited excellent ORR/OER catalytic activity. In addition to the loading of commonly used single-metal atoms such as Fe and Co on carbon fiber-based substrates, some other elements such as Mn, Ni, Mo, Cu, etc. can also be well loaded on carbon fiber-based substrates to improve the oxygen electrocatalytic performance of the substrate. For example, Zhou et al. [149] designed and prepared novel self-supported hollow fiber enriched with Ni-N4 monoatomic edge sites, in which Ni clusters were introduced to catalyze the in-situ growth of carbon nanotubes and preferentially anchor the monoatomic Ni-N sites. The experimental results and DFT calculations also showed that the Ni-N4 edge sites exhibited significant charge redistribution and asymmetry compared to in-plane, and a significant spin polarization with more unpaired electrons can be detected in the edge sites. Thus, the above calculations show modulation of the electronic configuration of the Ni-N4 edge-rich sites. This facilitates the adsorption/desorption behavior of the reaction intermediates (Fig. 10e) and promotes the catalytic properties. Based on the above discussion, it is not difficult to see that in the current studies about doping single metal atoms on carbon fiber-based substrates, some researchers generally use N-doped carbon fiber-based materials as the substrates and then form M−N−C structures between metal atoms and N-doped carbon fiber-based carriers through different metal precursors and in-situ growth methods. Most of the central metal atoms commonly used in current studies are transition metal atoms (such as Fe, Co, Cu, Mn, Ni, etc.). These different central metal atoms are usually regarded as the active sites of the ORR/OER reaction. Therefore, these factors may have different effects on the final catalytic performance. In addition, N atoms as ligand atoms also affect the performance of the catalysts due to their positions on the carbon fiber-based matrix, synergistic interactions with different metal atoms, and the number of N atoms. Therefore, in order to further effectively promote the development of M−N−C structured catalysts, more in-depth studies on their modification strategies are still needed. The potential synergistic or inhibitory effects between various atoms/groups also should be considered in greater depth.
