In addition, some efforts should be made to find some descriptors related to the chemical structure or intrinsic catalytic activity of the active sites, which will greatly provide a precise theoretical basis for the future designs of well-designed M−N−C type catalysts. 4.2.2 Single-metal compound doping In addition to being present as single atoms, transition metals can also be doped as compounds (e.g., oxides, phosphides, sulfides, etc.). The latter has emerged as highly promising candidates for bi-functional electrocatalysts, attracting extensive attention from researchers due to their high efficiency, abundant reserves, low cost, ease of preparation, and environment friendly. Transition metal oxides (TMOs) have received more and more attention due to their diverse crystal structures, abundant reserves, environmental friendliness, ease of preparation, and high activity. Manganese oxides are often considered promising transition metal oxide catalysts due to their high abundance in nature, low cost, and environmental friendliness. MnO x -based electrocatalysts have been widely employed as oxygen electrocatalysts due to their multivalent states and capacities to form diverse crystal structures. For example, Chen et al. [150] grew MnO x in situ on CC by simple chemical bath deposition and modulated the crystalline structure of MnO x by thermally-driven phase transition to improve the bi-functional catalytic activity for ORR/OER, which was shown to undergo a phase transition from MnO2 to Mn3O4 in the experimental procedure (Fig. 11 a). In addition, Co3O4 is also a promising bi-functional ORR/OER catalyst for its high electrocatalytic performance and tunable compositional structure [151]. It has been demonstrated that the enrichment of Co2+ on the catalyst surface can improve the OER performance [152], and Xiao et al. [153] showed that Co2+ can also play a catalytic role in ORR. Based on this example, Chen et al. [154] successfully grew ultra-thin mesoporous Co3O4 nanofilms in-situ on the surface of CF. These were employed as air electrodes for high-performance rechargeable ZABs, exhibiting excellent ORR and OER catalytic performance, corresponding to more than 10 times the activity of commercial Co3O4/CC electrodes. Furthermore, the oxygen electrocatalytic properties of Co3O4 can be modified by altering its structure or size. For example, Guan et al. [155] used Co-MOF as a precursor to restrict the Kirkendall effect via carbon onion coating. This phenomenon resulted in the conversion of Co NPs into irregular hollow Co3O4 nanorods with a fine nanoparticle structure, which had a high density of steps and grain boundaries and also contained more catalytically active sites and short ionic diffusion lengths, resulting in excellent bi-functional oxygen electrocatalytic activity. Transition metal sulfides (TMDs), which possess a two-dimensional layered structure and exhibit excellent electrical conductivity and acid-base stability, are widely distributed in the Earth's crust. The chemical valence states of S atoms are variable, which can result in the formation of different redox pairs during the catalytic process. Consequently, these TMDs have the potential to be a cost-effective and promising electrocatalyst. Among the numerous TMDs, theoretical calculations have demonstrated that Co-based sulfides usually exhibit high oxygen reactivity due to their favorable kinetics in reactions analogous to those of noble metals [156]. For instance, Liu et al. [157] successfully synthesized high-purity CoS nanosheets directly on the surface of CC. This resulted in a high ORR current density and a considerable OER current density. Furthermore, the material demonstrated excellent durability over a continuous measurement period of over 12 h. For example, Xie et al. [158] designed and prepared the Ni3S2-doped self-supported hollow fiber by calcination and sulfuration processes (Fig. 11b). The corresponding DFT calculations demonstrated that the OER activity was attributed to the interaction between Ni3S2 and SNCNT, while the ORR activity was attributed to the S, N co-doping in the heterojunction unit. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are highly resistant to alkali and corrosion, and their special structures are conducive to the adsorption of OH intermediates and precipitation of O2 [159]. The electronic coupling between phosphides and transition metals can also provide depleted d-orbitals on the metal and increase the electron density on the surrounding non-metal, thus inducing interfacial charge polarization and breaking the scaling relationship [160,161], which greatly improves the electrocatalytic activity. For instance, Gao et al. [162] successfully loaded Co2P onto N-P co-doping porous CNFs by electrospinning way and carbonization. The catalyst showed high ORR/OER performance, and the ZABs assembled from Co2P@CNF exhibit excellent charge/discharge stability (Fig. 11c). Similarly, Hu et al. [163] successfully loaded CoP onto CF at an annealing temperature of 900 °C and achieved excellent ORR/OER performance. When used as an air cathode for high-performance ZABs, it can be continuously operated with a stable energy round-trip of about 60%, which was superior to the Pt/C+RuO2 benchmark. Recently, Wang et al. [164] also took advantage of the nanosurface as well as a transition metal and heteroatom doping to co-dope Mo, N, and P onto the pretreated CC, which had a bark-like surface structure. And this special structure can increase the stability of self-supported electrodes, and the results showed that it had excellent bifunctional catalytic activity, and its ORR activity mainly originated from the N element, while the OER activity was mainly derived from the P element. In summary, in carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts modified by doping with monoatomic compounds, the tunable catalytic activity mainly originates from the electronic interactions between metal ions and non-metal anions. When monometallic compounds are doped again with other heteroatoms, these post-doped heteroatoms may greatly improve their reaction kinetics by modulating physicochemical properties such as vacancies, distortions and surface hydrophilicity. It may also improve the catalytic properties of monometallic compounds by changing the conductivity, electronic energy band structure, local charge distribution, etc. It also can be seen that the structure of the monometallic compound itself, the type, concentration and position of the post-doped heteroatoms all have a large effect on the catalytic performance. Therefore, there is a need to design controllable synthetic schemes to control and regulate the above factors precisely and to modulate further the catalytic performance of the monatomic compound-doped carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts. 4.3 Polymetals and their compounds doping Single-metal doped catalysts have a fixed electronic structure and a singular active metal atom, making it difficult to break the linear relationship between catalytic activity and the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates. In contrast, some catalysts with two or more metal doping have synergistic interatomic interactions and optimized electronic structures, which can be used to promote the proton-electron transfer on the metal sites through its strain effect or electronic effect, thus endowing these catalysts with excellent oxygen electrocatalytic activity. 4.3.1 Bimetallic monoatomic doping The co-doping of two metal single atoms on a carbon fiber-based conductive substrate can provide two potential reaction sites due to its two sets of single-atom structures, and different single atoms can play different functions in the catalytic reaction. The synergistic effect of the two can not only maximize the atom utilization rate but, more importantly, improve the catalytic selectivity [165]. Some advantages of bimetallic atom doping are summarized in three specific areas [166]: (1) modulation effects (in metal-atom pairs, one of the metal atoms acts as the active site and its electronic structure can be affected by the other metal atom); (2) collaborative effects (in metal atom pairs, both metal atoms play the role of active sites, which can adsorb different intermediates in the ORR or OER and thus work together to achieve catalysis); (3) bi-functional effect (two metal sites in a pair of metal atoms catalyze ORR and OER, respectively). Therefore, bimetallic atom doping can improve the catalytic activity and stability of ORR/OER by increasing the metal atom loading, changing the adsorption configuration and optimizing the reaction pathways [167]. Co, Zn, Fe, Ni, etc. are commonly used monometallic atoms, all of which when co-doped on a conductive substrate, exhibit oxygen electrocatalytic properties superior to those of single doping [168]. It has been reported that in alkaline media, the ORR activity of transition metals follows the order Fe > Co > Ni, whereas the OER activity follows the order Ni > Co > Fe. Therefore, bi-functional catalysts can be obtained when Co metal is co-doped with other metal atoms [169]. For example, Zhou et al. [170] designed and prepared novel self-supported hollow fibers consisting of N, P and Fe-Co diatomic sites, and the corresponding DFT calculations showed that the OER RDS step is O*→OOH*, and the ORR RDS step is OH*→H2O, and in both ORR/OER RDS steps, FeCo-NPC has a lower limiting barrier than these of the other models. Meanwhile, the asymmetric diatomic sites and the localized electronic engineering of the P-doped sites together reduce the formation energy of the RDS (Fig. 12 a), resulting in excellent oxygen electrocatalytic performance. In addition to bimetallic alloy doping based on Co metal, loading the rest of the metal atoms onto the carbon-based fiber through certain strategies can also likewise improve the oxygen electrocatalytic activity of the electrocatalyst. For example, Lai et al. [14] synthesized independent bi-functional electrodes with an excellent performance consisting of NiFe-PBA, N-doped carbon nanofibers (NCF) and CC mediated by CN vacancies (VCN). Similarly, Zhao et al. [171] also synthesized the robust and highly active FeNi@NCNTs nanowire arrays on CC by simple CVD and used them directly as integrated air electrodes for ZABs with excellent catalytic performance. Previous experimental and theoretical studies have demonstrated that the M−N−C structure is a promising catalyst for noble metal substitutes, and therefore, the introduction of other metal atoms based on this structure can also more efficiently modulate the electronic structure of the atomic part and improve the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity through the electronic coupling. For example, Tian et al. [172] coated Ni nanoparticles on Fe-N4 modified hollow CF to promote the bi-functional activity of ORR/OER. The related DFT calculations showed that compared to Fe-N4-C, Fe-N4-C||Ni was used for OER to form OOH* with a lower energy barrier and easier desorption of OH* in the ORR (Fig. 12b). The results also suggest that metal Ni doping can significantly affect the ORR and OER activities of the Fe-N4 sites by modulating their electronic structures, thus providing more favorable reaction kinetics for oxygen electrocatalysis. Recently, Ma et al. [173] prepared bimetallic ZIFs CNFs membranes with hierarchical porous structure by using coaxial electrospinning way and carbonization process, and their ORR properties were derived from the bimodal monatomic reactive sites of Co-N4 and Zn-N4 formed during the preparation process, while their excellent OER properties were derived from agglomerated metallic Co nanoparticles (Fig. 12c). 4.3.2 Bimetallic compound doping In addition to doping with two metal single atoms, bimetallic compounds have been widely used in oxygen electrocatalysis. These obtained compounds also exhibit excellent catalytic properties due to their unique electronic band structure and good chemisorption abilities. The applications of single metal compound doped carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts in oxygen electrocatalysis have been described in Section 4.2.2, but the doping of the second metal atom on a single transition metal compound to modulate the electronic structure of the metal compound is also an operative approach to improve the performance of oxygen electrocatalysis. In this regard, doping Co-based oxides with foreign atoms, like transition metals, may considerably boost their electrocatalytic activity for ORR and OER. The outcome is because the kinetic potential barrier of the catalytic procedure can be lowered due to the exchange of charge between the foreign atom and the subject and its modified electronic structure [174]. The activity of Co-based oxides in oxygen electrocatalytic reactions can also be enhanced by adjusting their valence distribution, improving their charge transport properties, or increasing their surface adsorption capacity. For example, Wang et al. [175] successfully doped Pd metal on Co3O4-loaded CNFs and used them as self-supported electrodes, in which the doping of Pd significantly increased the proton transfer rate and improved the reaction kinetics, effectively enhancing the catalytic performance. Bimetallic oxides (BOs), bimetallic sulfides (BSs), etc. have also obtained much focus due to their high catalytic efficiencies. In this respect, Pan et al. [24] successfully loaded CuCo2S4 nanosheets onto N-doped carbon nanofiber films, which exhibited excellent bi-functional catalytic properties and excellent mechanical flexibility. Similarly, Shi et al. [176] constructed the MnCo-based MOFs derived non-homogeneous MnS-CoS nanocrystals and anchored them on free-standing N-doped porous carbon fiber by in-situ growth method and sulfuration process. The DFT calculations showed that the non-homogeneous MnS-CoS nanocrystals were able to lower the reaction barrier and enhance the conductivity and adsorption of intermediates of the catalysts, thus exhibiting excellent catalytic performance, and the flexible solid-state ZABs assembled by them as self-supported air cathodes had excellent properties. Metal oxides like Fe, Co, Cu, and Ni are excellent electrocatalysts with moderate bi-functional catalyst activity in alkaline electrolytes. However, their catalytic activities remain unsatisfactory due to sluggish kinetics. For the past few years, some researchers have focused on developing highly active catalysts by co-doping the two metal oxides onto conducting substrates. For example, Sun et al. [177] fabricated self-supported air electrodes with adhesion and flexibility by electrospinning, carbonization and oxidation processes (Fig. 13 a), which had a special layered nanostructure consisting of haphazardly allocated Co3O4/Fe2O3 NPs, hierarchical lamellar arrays and carbon nanofiber networks. The synergistic effect of 3D hierarchical porous nanostructures and abundant accessible active sites resulted in excellent bi-functional electrocatalytic activities comparable to those of precious Pt/C and RuO2, respectively. Besides, spinel oxides have a variety of valence states that can provide receptor chemisorption centers for the reversible adsorption of O2, leading to efficient catalysis of ORR/OER [178]. Chen et al. [179] prepared self-supported spinel cobalt-manganese oxide (CMO) catalysts embedded in the N-doped CNFs in-situ by electrospinning technique and used them for the construction of ZABs and exhibited excellent bi-functional activity and long-term cycling stability for ORR/OER. As previously stated, bimetallic alloys exhibit excellent bi-functional catalytic activity and are suitable for use in rechargeable ZABs. However, these alloy particles still exhibit low activity and poor stability in harsh industrial environments, which precludes their commercial applications. To address this issue, some researchers have accelerated the charge transfer process by constructing heterojunctions between the alloys and the transition-metal-based heterojunctions, thus improving the catalytic activity and stability. The formation of heterojunctions can alter the electron density of the atoms around the interfaces, thereby effectively resolving the problem of inferior electrical conductivity in metal-activated materials. In the past few years, the constructions of O vacancies [180] and Co vacancies [181] on conducting substrates have been suggested to significantly enhance the catalytic activity of the substrates by improving the electronic structure, electron transfer capacity and charge density. Since S atoms can generate more active sites and/or modulate the electronic grouping of the metal surface, many tested results also presented that the catalytic activity by constructing Co-based sulfide heterostructures can be improved. For instance, Li et al. [182] successfully constructed CoS2/Cu2S heterostructures with flexible self-supported CNFs, where CoS2/Cu2S heterojunctions served as the primary active sites, resulting in a notable enhancement in electrochemical performance (Fig. 13b). On the other hand, Wang et al. [183] constructed N/S co-doped carbon nanotube heterostructures anchored by CoFe/Co0.2Fe0.8S particles on CC, and the corresponding DFT calculations showed that the synergistic effects of bimetallic components, built-in interfacial potentials, and chemical reconstruction of the surfaces together tuned the Fermi level and optimized the O* to OOH* thermodynamic formation, thereby increasing the intrinsic activity. In addition to Co-based sulfides, heterogeneous structures consisting of other types of metal compounds also have good catalytic properties. For instance, Bai et al. [184] loaded a CoP/CoN heterostructure on CC. Both theoretical calculations and experimental results demonstrated that the excellent catalytic performance was attributed to the highly dispersed active sites and the synergistic effect of Co-N x -C with ORR and OER activities and CoP with OER and HER activities (Fig. 13c). Recently, Li et al. [185] also designed an N, S-doped CNFs-loaded Co-based heterogeneous material (Co/Co3O4/CoF2@NSC CC) composite catalyst, and the composite had abundant nano-channels and optimized electronic configuration, which enabled the catalyst to exhibit excellent bi-functional ORR/OER catalytic activity and ZABs performance. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have a sandwich structure [186] (Fig. 13d), which is inexpensive, simple to prepare, diverse in composition and stable. The high accessible active surface area and good mechanical stability of LDHs enable them to provide a high theoretical specific capacity and good cycling stability [187]. LDHs exhibit excellent OER performance but poor ORR performance. The low electrical conductivity and susceptibility to agglomeration of LDHs greatly hinder their applications in electrochemical reactions. Consequently, some researchers usually combine LDHs with other excellent ORR catalysts to promote their bi-functional activities. For example, LDHs can be integrated with carbon materials such as CF, CNT, and CC to take advantage of their high specific surface area and porosity to improve ion transport and electrical conductivity and increase the number of active sites, thus improving the bi-functional electrocatalytic performance [188]. Recently, Liu et al. [189] successfully designed and prepared a flexible 3D self-supported NiFe-LDH@Co-NC/CC heterostructure, in which Co NPs anchored on N-doped porous carbon nanosheets were able to provide abundant active sites for the ORR reaction, and through altering the local electronic structures of Ni and Fe species in NiFe-LDH can effectively promote the OER reaction rate. Thus, the catalyst has great bi-functional catalytic activities and can be used in high-performance flexible ZABs. 4.3.3 Trimetal and their compounds doping Multimetallic alloys have also shown promising performance in metal-air battery applications, where the synergistic interactions between many different types of transition metals, heteroatom-containing species, and porous carbon skeletons can enrich the locally active catalytic sites and modify their electronic structures to lower the kinetic barriers and further facilitating the electrocatalytic process [190,191]. Therefore, the doping of multimetallic alloys has also attracted considerable attention from some researchers. Multimetallic oxides also exhibit the desired OER/ORR performance, charge/discharge efficiency, stability, and robustness through a multi-step electron transport process facilitated by increasing overall compositional entropy, lattice distortion, and synergistic effects [192–194]. Recently, Meng et al. [33] prepared an N and FeCoNi co-doped fiber by taking advantage of the nature of organic salts in the polymer solution. The obtained catalyst benefited from the secondary growth of FeCoNi and N-doped carbon nanotubes on the surface of the fiber, which generated a large number of M−N−C ORR active sites and FeCoNi alloy-based OER active sites. At a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the obtained FeCoNi FCNFs exhibited an ORR half-wave potential of 0.92 V and an OER half-wave potential of 1.64 V, which exceeded the commercially available noble metal catalysts. In the same year, Yao et al. [195] loaded NiGa alloys onto Ti4O7 by electrospinning method and then embedded them in P-rich CNFs, which together formed self-supported electrocatalysts with excellent bi-functional catalytic activities. In conclusion, the method of co-doping three or more metals and their compounds onto carbon fiber-based substrates can combine the properties of different metals to achieve complementary and optimized catalytic performance, thereby increasing their catalytic efficiencies. However, when compared to mono-metal or bimetallic doping, the research in this area is still insufficient. Therefore, it is necessary to strengthen the research on multi-metal doped carbon fiber-based substrates to take full advantage of their practical applications and promote scientific and technological progress in related fields. In summary, when heteroatom doping is carried out on carbon fiber-based conductive substrates, it can induce charge recombination, produce strain and bring structural defects in the carbon material. At the same time, it also can change the charge density of the carbon materials, which in turn improves its catalytic activity and stability. For example, when heteroatoms are loaded onto the surface of carbon materials, the surface properties (such as alkalinity chelating ability, surface roughness, and wettability, etc.) are modulated. Whereas when heteroatoms are doped into the carbon skeleton, the electronic band structure (such as Fermi energy levels, bandgap, charge distribution, etc.) is altered, and both types of doping can modulate the catalytic activity and stability of these carbon materials. Unlike heteroatom doping, when metal atoms are doped on carbon fiber-based conducting substrates, the special d-orbitals of transition metals can both provide and accept electrons, which can produce an effective reaction basis for catalytic reactions. In addition, some researchers also have found that transition metals and their compounds can reasonably adjust the microstructure of carbon materials by affecting the π-bonds, thus improving their stability [196]. Moreover, metal ions also have more variable valence states than heteroatoms, which can further optimize the electron affinity of the active center and accelerate the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction. When a single metal is doped onto a carbon fiber substrate, an M−N−C structure can be formed between the two kinds of materials, which can stabilize the metal atoms and promote the adsorption and desorption of intermediates. When other heteroatoms or metal atoms are doped again based on this structure, the catalytic activity and stability will be further increased due to the synergistic effect between these atoms. In addition, the heterojunction formed between the metal atoms also can regulate the charge density of the surrounding carbon atoms to further improve its stability. In addition to the above discussions, carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts can also act as excellent electrocatalysts in stand-alone ORR/OER reactions to enhance their reaction rates. The current commercial ORR catalysts are generally based on precious metal catalysts such as Pt. Due to its disadvantages, such as high cost and poor long-term stability, the large-scale development of ORR processes was seriously limited. Therefore, some researchers started to develop a series of self-supported catalysts based on carbon fiber materials for ORR processes [197–204] (Table 2 ). Similar to the ORR reaction, the catalysts currently used for the OER reaction are generally noble metal-based catalysts such as RuO2. Its shortcomings, such as low reserves and high costs, greatly limit the development of the OER reaction. Therefore, many researchers have developed carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts for the OER reaction [205–226] (Table 3 ). 5 Conclusions and outlook Driven by the current problems of energy shortage and environmental crisis, there is an urgent need to develop new green and efficient energy sources, and oxygen electrocatalytic reaction is a key reaction in many energy devices, so the development of excellent ORR/OER catalysts has become a goal of many researchers. When compared with conventional electrocatalysts prepared using powdered catalyst slurry, self-supported electrocatalysts with in situ growth active catalytic materials have some advantages of diverse synthesis methods, high active substance loading, controllable surface hydrophilicity, and good mass transfer performance. Of all the self-supported substrates available, carbon fiber materials have many unique properties, such as a wide choice of precursors, a wide range of material sources at low cost, good flexibility, outstanding electrical conductivity and stability. Therefore, the prepared self-supported electrocatalysts using carbon fiber as a conductive substrate also have the following advantages: (1) excellent electrical conductivity; (2) easy charge migration; (3) enhanced accessibility to catalytically active sites; and (4) outstanding stability. Herein, this review summarizes the commonly used methods for the preparation of CNFs-based self-supported air electrodes, i.e. electrospinning way and coaxial electrospinning method derived from conventional electrospinning, as well as in situ growth of catalysts on other carbon fiber-based materials (e.g. CF, CC, CFP, etc.), such as hydrothermal/solvent-thermal methods, CVD, electrochemical deposition, etc. In addition, this review provides a brief overview of the modulation strategies of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts and systematically discusses the important contributions of different self-supported electrocatalysts to ORR/OER in terms of different types of atomic doping, including heteroatom, monometallic, bimetallic and polymetallic doping. According to this review, it is not difficult to find that carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts are now continuously developing towards high performance, flexibility, environmental friendliness and multifunctionality. In the design of high-performance catalysts, researchers optimize the electrocatalytic performance by adjusting the composition, structure and morphology of the catalysts, and regulating the active sites of the catalysts through doping, alloying, surface reconstruction and so on. At the same time, researchers also use the corresponding DFT theoretical calculations and in-situ analyses to explore the underlying mechanisms of the performance enhancement, which will guide future research, and thus continue to push forward the research progress of various ORR/OER catalysts. Based on the above discussion, it can be found that carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts have important practical applications and research significance in the field of oxygen electrocatalysis. Since both ORR and OER reactions mainly occur at the gas-liquid-solid three-phase interfaces which is a non-homogeneous reaction, excellent electrocatalysts not only need to provide good reaction activity sites but also need to ensure the mass and charge transfer at the three-phase interfaces. In other words, the activity sites, mass transfer and charge transfer rates as well as the cost and stability of the catalysts are the key factors to be considered in the design of electrocatalysts. Therefore, the design of a carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalyst with excellent performance needs to consider the following design principles: (1) Increasing the number of catalytic active sites: The number/density of active sites is one of the key factors to achieving the excellent performance of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts. Due to the large specific surface area of the carbon fiber-based substrate itself, the catalyst surface geometry can be reasonably adjusted by reducing the size of the loaded actives, or by rationally designing the morphology and composition (Such as hollow, core-shell, hierarchical porous structure, etc.) to increase the number of exposed active sites and maximize the accessibility of the catalytic sites. (2) Enhancing the intrinsic activity of catalytic active sites: The intrinsic activity of catalyst active sites is the root of its catalytic activity and the fundamental factor affecting the catalytic efficiency. Therefore, the intrinsic activity of the catalytic active sites can be greatly improved by doping methods, defect engineering, and surface/interface engineering. (3) Increasing the charge transfer rate at the three-phase interfaces: For further improving the catalytic efficiency of the carbon fiber-based self-supporting electrocatalysts, the intrinsic conductivity can be optimized by adjusting the composition of the active substances, and the electrical conductivities of the electrocatalysts can also be further increased by further modulating the carbon fiber-based substrate to accelerate the charge transport and electron transfer. Although significant progress has been made in the design of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts, their preparation and modification ways for the electrocatalysts are still in their infancy, and there are still many bottlenecks restricting their development. However, the electrical conductivity of CC is usually poorer than that of foam metal, which seriously affects its catalytic ability. In addition, when using CC as a conductive substrate, it is generally necessary to treat it with HNO3 to eliminate the residual organic matter in commercial CC, and this pre-treatment also increases the cost on top of the extra energy consumed, so further researches are still needed to improve its conductivity: (1) further development of different preparation methods for more efficient and low-cost carbon fiber based self-supported electrocatalysts; and (2) exploration of different advanced strategies, such as improving the morphology of carbon fiber-based materials, constructing intrinsic defects, and structuring catalysts at the nanoscale. In addition, the future development of oxygen electrocatalysts for practical applications in energy devices still requires additional research efforts to address several scientific and technological challenges (Fig. 14 ). Firstly, a more systematic study of carbon fiber-based materials is needed to gain a fundamental understanding of the effects of size, surface morphology, roughness and fiber structure of carbon fiber on oxygen electrocatalytic performance. For example, the size of the fiber directly affects its specific surface areas, which in turn has an impact on the number of catalytically active sites. The surface morphology and roughness of the fiber also affect the mode of contact between the fiber and the reactants and the reaction kinetics, which in turn affects the contact area with the reactants and the reaction efficiency. In addition, the catalytic properties of the fiber can be further optimized by modulating their pore structures and lattice arrangements. Consequently, through the targeted adjustment of various physical properties of carbon-based fiber, it is possible to further enhance their catalytic performances as conductive substrates. For example, the degree of graphitization of the carbon fiber-based substrates can be greatly improved by selecting a suitable graphitization temperature, heat treatment time and drafting force, thereby effectively enhancing the corrosion resistance and electrical conductivity of the carbon fiber-based substrates. In addition, the intrinsic catalytic activity of the carbon fiber-based conductive substrate can also be improved by constructing a carbon fiber-based conductive substrate with hollow or porous structures. Secondly, the developed majority of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts thus far are only capable of operating in alkaline conditions and the appropriate temperature range, which restricts their versatility in practical applications due to the limited range of environments they can withstand. Consequently, based on a comprehensive understanding of the impact of acidic and neutral conditions on the performance of oxygen electrocatalysis, developing a bi-functional oxygen electrocatalyst that can function effectively across the full pH and wide temperature range represents a significant area of potential advancement. For example, the precious metals Pt, Ru, Ir, etc., which have excellent stability in their own right, can be modified so that they can stably perform catalytic effects even under acidic or neutral conditions. Moreover, in the development of non-precious metal-carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts, some strategies such as N-doping, synergistic heteroatom-doping, defective doping, and structure modulation can also be used to achieve their catalytic performances under acidic or neutral conditions. In addition, high-performance oxygen electrocatalysts under acidic conditions can also be theoretically explored by the DFT theoretical calculations and machine learning (ML) methods, and the results also can be applied to guide practical research works [227]. Thirdly, the outstanding advantage of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts over traditional powder catalysts is their chemical and mechanical stabilities due to the in-situ growth of the active materials and the excellent flexibility of the carbon fiber-based materials. However, during the ORR/OER reaction process, the carbon fiber-based carriers may undergo oxidative corrosion resulting in interfacial instability, which can lead to the shedding of active substances and reduce the overall stability of the prepared catalysts. Therefore, the stability of the catalysts can be greatly improved by increasing the degree of graphitization of the carbon fiber-based carriers, using dual atom catalysts (DACs) to improve 4e− selectivity in the ORR process [228], introducing “radical inhibitors” to inhibit the destruction of active sites by free radicals [229], or constructing dual-site oxide catalysts [230,231]. Fourthly, most of the currently reported studies involve expensive carbon precursors and corrosive or highly hazardous gases such as high-temperature NH3 or H2 treatments, which are environmentally stressful and hazardous, and therefore, it is necessary to develop more safe and environmentally friendly synthesis methods. For example, CO2 atmosphere treatment can be used to increase the number of active sites by generating multiple channels inside the fibers [185]. Furthermore, it is crucial to consider the recycling and disposal of catalysts. These catalysts can be achieved by developing or designing effective catalyst regeneration technologies to reduce the waste of catalysts and environmental pollution. Additionally, it is essential to identify suitable methods for the disposal of waste catalyst materials to prevent secondary pollution to the environment. Fifthly, although the subject of this review is self-supported electrocatalysts with carbon fiber as the conductive substrate, other fibers can also be used as excellent conductive substrates, such as plant fiber, metal fiber, and so on. Natural plant fiber, such as lotus fiber, exhibits excellent mechanical properties and biocompatibility, as well as a natural porous structure that facilitates the diffusion and transport of gases, thus promoting the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction. On the other hand, metal fibers also have much higher electrical conductivity than carbon-based fibers, and their morphological structures can also be tuned by precise processing to optimize the interfacial structure between them and the electrocatalysts, further improving the catalytic performance. Therefore, more efficient and stable self-supported electrocatalysts can be developed through an in-depth study of the electrical conductivities, morphological structures of different fiber materials, and their interactions with electrocatalysts. This research will promote the advancement of the electrocatalysis field. Sixthly, the distribution of active sites also is more homogeneous because the conventional powdered catalyst is uniformly dispersed on the conductive collector using a binder. When compared with traditional powder catalysts, although self-supported electrocatalysts can increase stability by avoiding the application of binders, catalysts of this structure may suffer from uneven dispersion of active substances on conductive substrates, and poor catalytic activity due to the uncertainty of process parameters, irrational structural design and inaccuracy of material selection during the in-situ growth process, which can reduce the catalytic efficiency and stability. Therefore, the degree of uniform dispersion of the active substance can be significantly improved by pre-treating the carbon fiber-based substrate before preparation, adjusting the ratio of the active substance to the carbon fiber-based substrate and the process parameters such as preparation time and speed. At the same time, developing a carbon fiber-based substrate loaded single-atom catalyst also is feasible to improve their stabilities, thereby avoiding aggregation of the active substances. Finally, various characterization methods currently applied to self-supported electrocatalysts are still those previously developed for powdered electrocatalysts. However, the differences in structure, morphology, and operating conditions between catalysts with self-supported structures and conventional powdered catalysts may present certain loopholes that prevent the comprehensive characterization of the intrinsic properties and catalytic performance of self-supported electrocatalysts. Therefore, more advanced methods need to be developed to investigate their actual performances under different device structures and electrolyte conditions. Some advanced spectroscopic and microscopic characterization techniques (such as electron microscopy, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, etc.) are extremely important for the characterization of the morphologies and electronic structures of carbon fiber-based substrates. Meanwhile, the identification of active sites is also an important step in the design of efficient electrocatalysts. The corresponding DFT calculations can help researchers effectively identify active sites and predict possible reaction intermediates, which in turn provides a theoretical basis for the rational design of the final catalyst. In addition, various in-situ characterization techniques also should be further developed and applied to these advanced tests to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the structural evolution of the active substances during the reaction processes. In conclusion, carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts show great potential for application in oxygen electrocatalysis because of their unique physical and chemical properties. In subsequent research, the catalytic mechanism should also be explored in depth by continuously optimizing the material design and synthesis method. Furthermore, the application of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts should be expanded in order to facilitate a significant contribution to the development and application of oxygen electrocatalysis technology. All of these will help to promote the development of new energy fields and achieve the goal of sustainable development and green energy. Feng, Chinese Chemical Letters. 35 (2024) 108798. Jinyu Han is currently pursuing a Master’s degree at Tiangong University. Her research focuses on the study and modification of high-performance ORR/OER electrocatalysts. Her current main research direction involves the preparation of modified materials using electrospinning technology and their application in ORR/OER reactions. Nanping Deng obtained his doctoral degree in Textile Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2018. Now, he is working as an associate professor and doctoral supervisor in Tiangong University. His research interests are the fundamental energy science and commercial application of electrospun nanofibers for solid-state lithium batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries and electrocatalysis. Hao Chi is currently pursuing a Master's degree at Tiangong University. Her main research direction is electrocatalytic conversion materials and related devices. Her current main research direction involves the application of electrospinning nano-micron fibers for electrocatalysis. Gang Wang currently holds a position at Dalian Polytechnic University and has earned his Ph.D. from Tiangong University. His primary research focus is on the development of nanofiber-based electrocatalytic conversion materials and related first-principles calculations based on density functional theory. As the first author, he has published articles in journals such as Small, JEC, JMCA, etc. Yilong Wang received a bachelor's degree in Textile Engineering from Tiangong University of Science and Technology, China in 2022. Now, he is studying for a master's degree at Tiangong University. His research interest is the preparation of electrocatalytic materials for oxygen electrocatalysis by electrostatic solution blowing. Qiang Zeng received his bachelor’s degree in nonwoven materials and engineering from Tiangong University. Now, he is pursuing his master’s degree at Tiangong University. He has long been engaged in the research of 1D ORR electrocatalysis for fuel cells. His current main research interest is to prepare modified electrocatalysts using electrostatic spinning technology and apply them to fuel cells. Zhaozhao Peng received his Bachelor's degree in Textile Science and Engineering from Tiangong University. Now, he is pursuing his master's degree at Tiangong University. He has been engaged in the functional design and performance research of electrolyte separators for lithium batteries for a long time. His current main research content is the preparation of functional nanofibers using electrospinning and electrostatic blowing techniques, and their application as electrolyte separators in lithium batteries. Bowen Cheng received his doctoral degree in Chemical Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2003, and studied in Hochschule Niederrhein, Germany as a doctoral exchange student in 2001. Then he was appointed as a research associate at the University of Leeds, England. He is currently a professor in Tiangong University. His research focuses on novel fiber materials, advanced functional nonwovens and smart textiles for energy harvesting and storage. Baoming Zhou has been working in Tiangong University, China since 2007, and obtained his Master degree in Textile Engineering from Tiangong University in 2009. His scientific interests are the design, preparation, and evaluation of various nanofibers. Weimin Kang has been working in Tiangong University, China since 2007, and obtained his doctoral degree in textile chemical engineering from Tiangong University in 2012. He was appointed to professor in 2017. His scientific interests are the design, preparation, and evaluation of novel nanofibers and their application in the fields of catalysis, filtration, energy harvesting, and storage.

coredata.dc:description: Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the key reactions in numerous renewable energy devices. Unlike conventional powdered catalysts, self-supported catalysts are extensively employed in oxygen electrocatalysis because of the enhanced electron-transfer rate, high specific surface area, and superior mechanical flexibility. Among the self-supported conductive substrates, carbon fiber usually exhibits several distinctive advantages, such as a straightforward preparation process, relatively low cost, good stability, and excellent conductivity. Against this background, carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts have been widely applied and studied in oxygen electrocatalysis, indicating a promising development direction in oxygen electrocatalyst research. Thus, it is essential to offer an overall summary of the research progress in this field to facilitate its subsequent development. Taking the regulatory mechanisms and modification methods as a starting point, this review comprehensively summarizes recent research on carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts in recent years. Firstly, a brief overview of the synthesis methods and regulatory mechanisms of carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts is given. Furthermore, the view also highlights the modification methods and research progress of self-supported electrocatalysts synthesized on carbon fiber-based substrates in recent years in terms of different dopant atoms. Finally, the prospects for the application of self-supported electrocatalysts based on carbon fiber in oxygen electrocatalysis and the possible future directions of their development are presented. This review summarizes recent developments and applications of self-supported bi-functional electrocatalysts with carbon fiber-based materials as the conducting substrate in oxygen electrocatalysis. It also lays a robust scientific foundation for the subsequent reasonable design of highly effective carbon fiber-based self-supported electrocatalysts.
